item.title: Least squares as springs
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: Physics intuition for regression and other methods that minimize squared error. We can imagine springs pulling the model toward the data.

item.title: Did the new variant of COVID spread through schools?
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: The common theory of the new COVID variant is that intrinsic biological factors make it more transmissible. An alternate theory attributes the same dynamics to social explanations like community spread among school-aged children.

item.title: Is the new variant of COVID really more transmissible?
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: A variant of COVID recently grew rapidly in London. Experts have warned this strain may be more transmissible, and governments have enacted more restrictions as a response. But the new variant has not spread rapidly in other locations.

item.title: Relocating and rebuilding
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: Some retrospective on an eventful 2020, announcing a move from New York to London, a couple book recommendations, and a new design for this website.

item.title: A concise defense of statistical significance
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: Recent arguments against the use of p-values and significance testing are mostly weak. The weak ones are actually arguments against making decisions or mistakes in general, which is impossible.

item.title: A conditional approach to inference after model selection
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: Model selection can invalidate inference, such as significance tests, but statisticians have recently made progress developing methods to adjust for this bias. This post motivates a conditional approach with a simple screening rule example and introduces an R package that can compute adjusted significance tests.

item.title: Model selection bias invalidates significance tests
item.dc:creator: Joshua Loftus
item.description: People often do regression model selection, either by hand or using algorithms like forward stepwise or the lasso. Sometimes they also report significance tests for the variables in the chosen model. But there's a problem: the reason for *p*-value significance may just be something called model selection bias.
